summary: Build an app to stream a single video source to multiple platforms (YouTube-first, extensible), with a quick-start flow enhanced by Google Drive/Docs-based input selection and stream health monitoring.
architectural_notes: Design platform-specific streaming integrations as modular adapters (start with YouTube; allow adding other platforms later).
Introduce a compositing/layer system (scene graph) to support Streamlabs-like overlays and multiple sources before outputting to platform adapters.
Add a quick-start path with sensible defaults that still maps to the underlying multistream session model.
If supporting Google Drive/Docs inputs, design a permissions/access-check step (and/or OAuth flow) to validate file visibility before starting a stream.
Define and version a strict, machine-parseable Google Docs content format (e.g., delimited blocks or JSON-like sections) to avoid being disrupted by unrelated text.
Introduce a stream health subsystem that aggregates client network checks and platform-side status (e.g., YouTube ingest/health) into a single UI indicator.

existing_features.title: Create a frontend workflow to define a single input video source and create a multistream session that targets multiple platforms, starting with YouTube.

Implement a platform-adapter framework (frontend + backend data model) so new streaming platforms can be added later without redesigning core session flows. The framework must support platform-specific fields and validation rules (e.g., YouTube ingest URL + stream key).

Add YouTube as the first supported platform, including the ability to configure RTMP ingest settings and show the user the resulting output endpoint details for use in external broadcasting/restreaming tools.
Persist multistream sessions and their non-sensitive configuration in the Motoko backend (single-actor), and load/update them from the React app using React Query.

Add a coherent, distinctive visual theme for the app (colors, typography, spacing, and component styling) and apply it consistently across all pages and states (empty, loading, error). Avoid blue/purple as the primary palette.
Add support for attaching a video media source to a streaming session so a user can select what video will be streamed.
Implement Streamlabs-like layer composition for a session, allowing users to create and manage an ordered list of visual layers (scene/overlay stack) that will be part of the stream composition.
Provide a quick-start workflow that lets a user go from zero to a started stream with minimal steps (create session, set video source, add at least one output target, then start).

Enhance the existing Quick Start flow (frontend/src/components/QuickStartDialog.tsx) to speed up repeated setup by offering: (1) a one-click random 'fireplace' session title suggestion, (2) a one-click 'Use previous title' option, and (3) auto-filling the Video Source URL with the previously used value when available.

Add explicit Google Drive share-link support messaging and validation in the Video Source URL inputs (Quick Start Step 2 in frontend/src/components/QuickStartDialog.tsx and the session Video Source panel in frontend/src/components/VideoSourcePanel.tsx): detect common Google Drive 'share' URL patterns and display required-permissions guidance to the user in English.

Add a 'Preset Import' slot to the Quick Start flow that lets a user paste structured entries (copied from a Google Docs file) containing video titles, RTMP ingest URL, stream key, and Google Drive video link; parse the pasted text using a strict format that is robust to other unrelated content in the document; allow selecting one parsed preset to auto-fill the Quick Start title, video source URL, and YouTube RTMP fields.

Add a 'Stream Health / Readiness' panel to the session details page (frontend/src/pages/SessionDetailPage.tsx) that provides (1) a network sufficiency warning based on browser-available network information and (2) a configuration readiness checklist that helps prevent common streaming failures (missing video source, missing output target, missing RTMP fields).

Provide a best-effort 'YouTube streaming verification' UX in the Stream Health / Readiness panel that helps the user confirm whether YouTube is actually receiving/playing the stream, without requiring Google/YouTube API keys: add an explicit manual verification workflow and allow the user to record a verification status per session locally.

Update the Quick Start UX copy and inline guidance to reflect Streamlabs/Prism-style failure avoidance: add concise, actionable tips at the point of input for common failure causes (permissions, incorrect RTMP URL vs stream key, missing video source, and starting before outputs are configured).

new_feature_requests.summary: Multiplatform streaming: take one video input and stream to multiple platforms, starting with YouTube and extensible to others via a modular framework
Allow adding/importing video media as a source to be streamed (manage the input media for a stream session)
Add Streamlabs-like layering/overlays (scene composition with multiple layers on top of the stream)
Provide a quick-start workflow to start a stream with minimal setup
Update backend state handling to safely evolve existing sessions to include the new video-source and layer fields without breaking existing persisted data during upgrade.
Quick-start: support Google Drive share links as video sources and surface required permissions/access checks to the user
Quick-start: speed up setup by suggesting a random 'fireplace' title or reusing a previously used title, and defaulting the video URL to the previously used one

Add stream health monitoring: show stream health, warn on insufficient network speed, and verify whether YouTube is actively streaming/ingesting
Research Streamlabs/Prism-like UX patterns and failure-avoidance best practices to improve streaming success rate and reduce setup errors
